values: This is a link to my friends' band's site, which is improving very quickly, by the way. If you like the music, or if you like me, you should post the same link in your journals. You do this by typing: a href="http://www.nex-online.net/">Nex With a < in front of the first a. Nex

List of things that annoy me:

Childish idealism.


Petulance. (You didn't even have permissive parents. What's with the tantrums?)


Compulsory faith. 


Self-destructive drug use. 


Attention-whoring emotionality.


Insincere apologies.


Smug philistine Americans. It should be its own nationality. Philistine-American.


Utter lack of emotional control.



I have soooo many things to point out to these people. You know what they would do? Scream at me!

Ah... the fruits of divine irony are bitterly addictive. 

(Psychologically. Like other substances. 
Cough.
Cough.
Anyway.)

Well! Aren't YOU pathological tonight!

They were dying as they ran. Beneath a bloodlit sky, they flashed, twinkled, flames licking up their fragile silhouettes. Like glittering trout pulled from the waves into a fiery sun, they flopped and twitched, crying out in desperation, dying there on the pale sand. In their moments of death, they became inhuman, beautiful and complete for an instant before their gasping and convulsing ceased.

-My thought of the day, which is a modification of a piece from a month ago.

One night a moth flew into the candle, was caught, burnt dry, and held. I must have been staring at the candle, or maybe I looked up when a shadow crossed my page; at any rate, I saw it all. A golden female moth, a biggish one with a two-inch wingspan, flapped into the fire, dropped her abdomen into the wet wax, stuck, flamed, frazzled and fried in a second. Her moving wings ignited like tissue paper, enlarging the circle of light in the clearing and creating out of the darkness the sudden blue sleeves of my sweater, the green leaves of jewelweed by my side, the ragged red trunk of a pine. At once the light contracted again and the moth's wings vanished in a fine, foul smoke. At the same time her six legs clawed, curled, blackened and ceased, disappearing utterly. And her head jerked in spasms, making a spattering noise; her antennae crisped and burned away and her heaving mouth parts crackled like pistol fire. When it was all over, her head was, so far as I could determine, gone, gone the long way of her wings and legs. Had she been new, or old? Had she mated and laid her eggs, had she done her work? All that was left was the glowing horn shell of her abdomen and thorax-a fraying, partially collapsed gold tube jammed upright in the candle's round pool.

And then this moth-essence, this spectacular skeleton, began to act as a wick. She kept burning. The wax rose in the moth's body from her soaking abdomen to her thorax to the jagged hole where her head should be, and widened into flame, a saffron-yellow flame that robed her to the ground like any immolating monk. That candle had two wicks, two flames of identical height, side by side. The moth's head was fire. She burned for two hours, until I blew her out.
She burned for two hours without changing, without bending or leaning-only glowing within, like a building fire glimpsed through silhouetted walls, like a hollow saint, like a flame-faced virgin gone to God, while I read by her light, kindled, while Rimbaud in Paris burnt out his brains in a thousand poems, while night pooled wetly at my feet...
 
-From Holy the Firm, by Annie Dillard

"I was three years old when I met the man who would eventually be my father," she says without a trace of sincerity. Her face is artlessly expressionless, her hazel eyes hollow beneath too many carefully-applied layers of ivory and charcoal. "I hated him on sight." Now she smiles, matter-of-fact and warm, as though this is the easy thing. Chewing one chipped black fingernail, she pauses. "Do you have a  cigarette?" I hand her one; she lights it. The flare of the Bic lighter bathes her lined face and short, matte-black hair in a sickly, hellish glow. Her silver rings sparkle with it. "Thanks." Taking a slow drag, she leans forward, her eyes buried in thought and the lapel of my business suit.

     "He was a thirtysomething genetic defect. Born and raised in Ransom Creek, population 250, so... I mean...
He was an old farm boy. I mean, that's basically what his whole family was, just a bunch of aging farm boys. Basically, blonde, blue-eyed, Scandinavian. And he always was kind of vain about that. I guess he thought he had boyish good looks or something, but really he was just fat and balding. And I mean, even though he had almost no hair left, he still carried around one of these little black combs, which always made me think of monkeys picking bugs out of their hair. And a used handkerchief, which he almost never washed, so it was always just too revolting to mention." She sighs, the sound ragged and exasperated. "He smelled like beer all the time. But I guess none of this is what you want to know, right?" She smiles at me, although her bright eyes do not shift to my face. I realize now that I never asked her age. She appears ancient and adolescent at turns, with the deeply-etched lines in her face sharply contrasted by the youthful tones of her voice. When I first caught sight of her on a crumbling street corner, she appeared fifteen, awkward in the transformation between child and woman. At that time, I named her the Gutter Princess in my mind, so her name does not matter. I decide to ignore her age as well.
    "I don't remember how old I was when it happened." At this point she holds up a hand for silence, although I have not spoken. "It isn't the kind of thing you're thinking. I wasn't abused or raped or anything. You can't look at me like I am now, and say, that's where it... this, what I am... came from. I mean, not obviously. Just let me tell you my story, and wait til I'm done before you try to judge it.
    "Like I said, I don't know how old I was. I was little, though, just a skinny little kid. My hair was really, really long, and I think I was going through a phase where I kept wearing Western shirts all the time, with finge and sequins. I mean, I had white cowgirl boots and a pink hat. Just stupid. I was young enough to be stupid like that, but I already knew enough to feel trapped in all the space of the prairie, the wide-open winter, where... I mean, everything reflected the sky and for some reason the sky always looked white. There were no trees, or cities or anything, just fence-posts and a few phone lines. And the sky felt like it just... it just came down on either side of the land, like a bubble to keep you in the prairie. It just smothered you and... And you couldn't get out. No one could get out." She is troubled by this for a moment, biting her lower lip, frowning into her reflection on the scratched table. I catch her attention and wave her on, pointing to the tape recorder.
   Sighing, she continues. "Anyway, it was the winter show..."
   "Winter show?" I mouth, putting one hand over the microphone. She blinks at me for a moment, uncomprehending, then nods.
   "...which is when farmers from everywhere around came and brought their... stuff... to show it off. They brought livestock, and grain, and tractors. And they had rodeos and tractor pulls. I mean the place just reeked of hay and manure and diesel. There was so much dust and hay in the air. I mean, allergy city." The gutter princess smiles wryly, takes another drag off the cigarette, and taps the ashes directly onto the table. "Anyway, I'm getting off-track here. Like I said, I was little. I hadn't gotten my glasses yet, so I remember the farmers were kind of a brown, hazy herd. And it was so loud there.
   "I was there because he wanted to gossip, drink, and watch the rodeo. He promised I could see the horses. I don't remember if I did or not. I remember everyone was milling around like cattle, this big, sweaty mass of people talking about things I didn't understand, so many people talking that none of them seemed to be talking. Just this loud... this babbling roar. I don't know."
   She falls silent for a moment; I can see her kohl-rimmed eyes now drifting over the cracked plaster behind me, and I know she sees nothing.
   "I was little, and shy, and way too sensitive for that place. At the rodeo, they kept tying up the baby animals. They kept throwing down the baby animals and tying them up. I remember that. Because everybody cheered... except the baby animals. They just looked so awkward and scared. The rodeo was... a terrible place for them. And he... And the rodeo made me sick to my stomach. I hated it, and everyone acted like I was so strange for hating to see it. So I went to see the other baby animals.

   "I remember there were baby pigs. They actually... snorted, just making these little... nose sounds." A soft sound that almost passes for a giggle escapes her lips, childlike but for the puff of smoke that accompanies it.

  "I liked the baby pigs, and the rabbit was okay too, but... over in the corner, by the wall, there was this little... pen. Just this tiny pen made of really thick wire." Her hands try to trace its shape in the air as she speaks, moving without her knowledge in graceless little jerks, the ember at the end of her cigarette dropping sparks. She pauses, bites her lower lip, then continues speaking. "What was in the pen was this little calf. She was a white calf, although really she was a little yellow. These huge dark eyes that just... just sparkled with intelligence and wariness. She looked shaggy and scruffy, but those eyes seemed so bright and... alive. She had long eyelashes, and around her nose, all these sensitive little hairs..."

   Her eyes find mine, startling in their intensity. This is the first time she has directly looked at me, and her gaze seems to plead for recognition. "I remember that. She was so beautiful and so alive, even though she was dirty and no one seemed to take care of her at all. I mean, even the little white plastic bowl her water was in, it was all grimy, and the water was just clouded up with dust and hay. And the pen was so small she was always against one side or another." The gutter princess sighs, then smiles.

   "But she still just looked so little in that pen, and so lonely and scared and just... trapped. I sat down by the pen and started just talking to her." Her voice trembles for a moment, and again she falls silent, inhaling, then exhaling deeply, the smoke swirling around her face like graveyard fog.

   "I loved her because she was just like me. She was so confused and lonely and scared. She was a little kid. I sat there and I told her everything. I told her about the winter, and how I missed my family. I asked her about her family, and told her I was glad she wasn't in the rodeo. I told her also not to be afraid of me. So then I thought, I wanted to pet her, because I wanted a friend. So I put my hand on her pen, but she moved away. She went as far as she could over to the other side of her little pen. And I wanted to pet her, but I also didn't want her to be scared or nip me. So I just kept talking to her, coaxing her, telling her what pretty black eyes she had, and how she didn't need to be afraid of me. It took me so long, but I just kept my hand right there on her pen and kept talking really quietly." Her hand has paused in the air, resting on an invisible pen, suspended in memory.

   "After a little while, she didn't look scared anymore. She kept sticking out her nose to sniff my hand, kind of wary, almost, not quite ever touching it. Her neck stretching out just as far as it could. And these huge eyes just kept flickering to look at me. She was so curious, like a little baby. It was sweet."

   A faint smile has spread over her face, and she runs her free hand through her hair, looking down at the battered tape recorder on the table.

   "I was so proud of myself. I really was. I had been so patient, waiting for her to be okay. And then-"

   Breaking off sharply, she sits very still, only breathing.

   "He came back then. He was so... loud. So loud and coarse. I kept talking to her like he wasn't there. He started talking to me, but I don't remember what he said. He was just so loud... He was so cocky. He just... He- I mentioned he was a farm boy. His father taught him to act a certain way. And he knew..." The sarcasm in her voice is unmistakable and savage. "He knew how to handle cattle. He told me I was doing this wrong, and he would show me how. With this smug little smile, you know? Just being a cocky bastard, basically. I told him no, but before- he just lunged at the poor little thing. He lunged at her... and he missed."

   She puts the cigarette down on her saucer. There is a chilling hatred in her eyes as she looks down at her delicate, deft hands. When she speaks again, her voice is hard, edged with an unconcealed contempt. "Just that lunge, just that one thing, that moment, that's what I've been trying to explain to you. The violence of it- him, with those stupid, blank eyes... And she was so tiny, and afraid, shivering back against the back of her cage, and her eyes were so... so intelligent, so there, so perfectly aware of what... so terrified.... That moment is all I remember very clearly... my stomach just felt like it was dropping. I had spent so long trying to calm this poor sweetheart down, trying to gain her trust. And he just completely shattered that. She was so... so awake, so completely, intensely in that moment... And he was fat, and mindless- basically, a cow..." She laughs bitterly, the sound harsh in its suddenness. Her eyes flicker to meet mine again, glinting, and I can see the glow of her cigarette in her quiet mascara tears. "He was so fucking ridiculous in that moment. Because he thought that since he was a human, he had this... divine right, or something, over this poor little calf. And that if he could just physically control that calf just by sheer brute force, that made him superior.... And he was so... so dumb, and contemptible, and ridiculous. And... and at the same time, almost pitiable... Because he missed. He fucking missed. You know?"

   Falling silent, the gutter princess smooths her short hair, flicks her lighter, and watches the flame.Her eyes glow for a moment. She puts the lighter down.

   "That's what I... that's why it matters, right? Because it's not just that one man. It's everybody. The whole fat, stupid, arrogant fucking mass of humanity. It's like a bloated corpse, it's like, after somoene drowns, right? It's not even human anymore. That's what it makes me think of. Because they.... because we all think we're beyond that. We could never be anything but human, no matter how senseless and... and ugly, and savage. And I mean, we feel like we have this natural superiority to everything else in the world, because we're human, and we're so advanced and all. But what it really comes down to is that lunge, that mindless, failed attempt to control everything and everyone fucking else, to just impose whatever we want where we have no right to do it. It wasn't just him. It's everybody. And..." She lifts a set of headphones from her torn, grey backpack, then places them around her neck. Pulling herself to her feet, she speaks in a pained, soft voice. She picks up her cigarette, inhales sharply, and then leans down to grind it out on the table, looking past me with troubled, haunted eyes.

   "It's everybody."

Pause.

Take one moment and just find yourself where you are. Close your eyes and listen to the breathing. Think: 

Within, power lingers that even I cannot control. Power that forces this breathing to continue. Power that only death can curb. Beyond, without, a world of lying compassion and blind idealism presses in upon me. My mind may collapse, but this power does not. Beyond, without, a world of hype and false happiness. A world of clothes, cars, work, suburbia, sterility. This world may collapse, but I do not.

Imagine:
A world of gaudy, sterile color. Shrill, plastic laughter, plastic families, plastic faces. Despite the fluorescent lights, this is a place of darkness. Veils, smiles, glass-eyed stares, and lies. In this world, you are one of many, all imprisoned by their plastic masks. Every sound you hear is muted, a mere remnant of what it once was, tinny and meaningless, driven through the churning of the machines and the roar of the crowds. To live in this world is to breathe underwater. There will be suffocation, panic, and lethal comfort. 

Look up.

You stand on a horizon line, beneath a sunset sky, blood-brilliant and streaked with gold. Distant stars merge and burst in chaotic constellations, unnerving, terrifyingly beautiful in their impossibility.
Take one step and you will be borne upward by the wind, borne alone into the fire and the wonder that you now see. This is a world of terror, of truth, of light, of chaos, of war, of unmistakable beauty. Killing fire, dying stars. Apocalypses played out again and again to thunderous symphonies. Flash. One step and your choice is made.

Few of you will comprehend the reality of this. Many have already seen the fiery horizon and turned away. The world you live in is a world of veils and hopelessness, of stagnancy and unconscious self-loathing. But there is a spark in each one of you that glitters, flares, glows with the restless desire to be lifted up out of the world's quagmire. You have the ability to cradle that flame, to nurse and feed the blaze until its brilliant, shifting, constant light consumes you. 

You stand on a horizon line beneath a sunset sky.
Take the step.
Make your choice.
